abstracts.cdata!:
The Agricultural Institutions Technical
            Assistance (ATIA) Project in Madagascar was achieved. The
            project has, through both its successes and its failures,
            taught a number of important lessons: First, studies of the
            rice sub-sector kind are often ignored, but the study was
            good enough and timely enough to be used as a catalyst to
            bring about a major policy reform. The rice crisis, the
            receptivity and astuteness of the Rural Development
            Minister, the willingness of decision-makers to be convinced
            by good analysis, the readiness of producers and merchants
            to respond to price signals: all of these conditions
            permitted the study to have a decisive impact. Of the four,
            only the existence of the crisis was knowable in advance.
            The lesson is simply this and no more. If certain key actors
            are receptive, technical assistance is capable of providing
            a seminal study that starts a process of policy reform.
